Award.AwardTitle: Deciphering BMP signaling and the role of Schnurri transcription factors using a deep sequencing approach in Xenopus
Award.AbstractNarration: BMPs were first identified for their bone-inducing properties. Subsequently it was discovered that BMPs control numerous events in embryonic development and adult tissue homeostasis including cell type specification, stem cell maintenance, cell death, and cell division. As BMPs play roles in a large variety of biological processes, defects in BMP activities are linked to various diseases including developmental defects and cancer. In order to further uncover the root causes of other developmental defects and diseases, identification of genes regulated by BMPs is essential. This project incorporates state-of-the-art molecular biology approaches to uncover the intricacies of BMP target gene regulation. The intellectual merits of this proposal are to provide a global view of BMP function in a depth that is unprecedented in the current literature. This project is likely to uncover the involvement of BMPs in various diseases and biological processes including the maintenance of stem cell properties. Findings from this project will also explain how BMP signaling has evolved to control development in different biological and evolutionary contexts. This project will also have an educational impact as over one dozen undergraduates and graduate students will be trained in the areas of molecular biology, developmental biology, and computational biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
BMPs control cell type specification, differentiation, pluripotency, apoptosis, proliferation, and tissue morphogenesis. BMP signaling is a highly conserved and widely used developmental signaling systems in animal evolution and study of the molecular mechanisms governing BMP signaling remains a major focus of developmental biology. With BMPs involved in so many different developmental events, this begs the following questions: When and where is BMP signaling activated during development?  What transcription factors mediate BMP signaling?  At the systems level, what role does BMP signaling play in the gene regulatory networks that control development? At the time when this project was initiated, we had a very limited understanding of how BMPs achieve their biological effects. Our work implicated the role of Smad1 and zinc finger DNA binding protein Shn. To gain a comprehensive understanding of the BMP signaling gene regulatory network, we applied the genome-wide approaches to examine the DNA binding property of Smad1 during very early stage of frog embryogenesis. We have identified over 1000 regions (peaks) that were bound by Smad1. Many of the Smad1 peak locations coincided with the open chromatin region of DNA and directly regulate the expression of dozens of genes. We also uncovered that in addition to Shn transcription factor, Smad1 has several other transcriptional factor partners to coordinate the expression of a battery of BMP target genes. Our finding is consistent with the view that Shn and Smad1 do not function in isolation or in linear pathways, but rather interact in complex webs or networks. Each developmental decision involves a large number of orchestrated transcriptional changes in batteries of cell-type-specific genes. During the course of current work we have also successfully adapted the CRISPR/Cas9 technology for the frog system, and demonstrated that this system can efficiently create mutations in the both alleles in F0 generation. Specifically, we targeted the tyrosinase gene (tyr), encoding the enzyme required in the biosynthesis of melanin during early development. Mutation of tyrosinase resulted in the oculocutaneous albinism and appearance of albino tissue at the expense of otherwise pigmented skin in the F0 generation at high frequency. This CRISPR/Cas9 technology will enable us to rapidly introduce mutations in the frog genome and create animals that are deficient in specific genes. Since mutations in genes regulating BMP signaling cause various diseases (e.g., juvenile polyposis syndrome, primary pulmonary hypertension, Cowden’s syndrome) and developmental abnormalities, this technology permits us to rapidly generate mutations for candidate BMP target genes and signaling components to better understand the underling mechanisms causing developmental defects and diseases.
